body: It's a known issue with multi monitor setups. This is essentially an extension of issue #188.

This sounds more like a xrandr (or whatever these Linux display settings things are called) issue, where they defined just one monitor by joining them together. By reducing the area, it will just start from the left side potentially ending up on the second monitor.

Without actually someone that can provide proper information on their setup and has the Linux knowledge required to understand how these monitor things work, there's little we can do at this point.

This issue also reminded me of #436, but we've switched back to Xlib in the mean time.

I had a problem when i tried to play @naezith's game. I couldn't change the resolution for borderless, windowed or fullscreen modes. After trying out different display configurations in my Desktop Environment, we tried to see what was SFML returning when Naezith's game called **getFullscreenModes**. We compiled SFML from the source code and ran a [sample code](https://gist.github.com/Yengas/ab23e1e68f30c01fd8b0cdf911899015). The sample application prints out the fullscreen modes returned by the SFML lib. After running the application, it prints out my current desktop resolution 7 times, with the exact same width and height.

So if i disable my second monitor and run the sample application i get this;
```
Total size of fullscreen modes: 7
1920x1080 # x7 times
```
With the second monitor enabled;
```
Total size of fullscreen modes: 7
3840x1080 # x7 times
```

SFML Version: **git c43b5991afe815ef92a812d67f8af12b0143adfd**
G++: **g++ (Ubuntu 5.4.1-2ubuntu1~16.04) 5.4.1 20160904**
Linux: **Linux berserk 4.4.0-77-generic #98-Ubuntu SMP Wed Apr 26 08:34:02 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux**
Linux Distro: **Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS**
Graphics Card: **Nvidia GTX 950M**
NVIDIA Driver Version: **381.09**

Also, we had to build the SFML according to this [comment on stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/39607844), it didn't work otherwise. Tell me if you need any other information regarding my setup. I will appreciate any insight on the issue.

A user of my game reported it. 
I reproduced the problem. The most annoying thing is that the monitor stays off after the application closed and windows are rearranged.

After some investigation, I found that XRRSetCrtcConfig should be used instead of XRRSetScreenConfig.

I gave it a try (https://github.com/bloodsword/SFML/tree/dual-monitor-fix).
It's not shutting down the screen anymore, but some WM (Cinnamon and Unity at least) do not switch the window to fullscreen when there are 2 monitors. 
Ubuntu WM was already suffering this problem without the fix, I guess it's the issue #1224. 
I have a fix for this issue but it's quite ugly, I will try to post it soon.

To use the mouse in the second screen, you need to alt+tab. 
This behavior suits my game, since screen edges are used to move the camera.
But I don't really understand why.

Here are some useful links :
https://www.reddit.com/r/gamedev/comments/2w8ahe/changing_resolutions_for_fullscreen_in_x11_linux
https://sourcecodebrowser.com/libxrandr/1.2.3/_xrandr_8h.html
@bloodsword Feel free to open a pull request. Makes it easier to review and allows our CI system to build it.

issue.title: Dual monitor fix
issue.body:
**SFML Tasks**

* [ ] Test and confirm fix by multiple people/distros/window managers

----

This should fix #1226.

XRRSetCrtcConfig is now used to set video mode  instead of XRRSetScreenConfig.

rename.from: Fullscreen runs on second monitor and closes the second one in dual monitor setup, Linux
rename.to: Fullscreen runs on second monitor and closes the main one in dual monitor setup, Linux
